contentrichtext.text: {{Literature}} {{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} '''Absurdist fiction''' is a genre of [[literature]], most often employed in [[novel]]s, [[Play (theatre)|play]]s or [[poem]]s, that focuses on the experiences of characters in a situation where they cannot find any [[meaning of life|inherent purpose in life]], most often represented by ultimately meaningless actions and events. Common elements in absurdist fiction include [[satire]], [[dark humour]], incongruity, the abasement of [[reason]], and controversy regarding the philosophical condition of being "nothing."<ref>{{Citation | last = Cornwell | first = Neil | title = The Absurd in Literature | isbn = 978-0-7190-7409-7 | year = 2006 | publisher = Manchester University Press | location = New York, NY}}</ref> Works of absurdist fiction often explore [[agnostic]] or [[Nihilism|nihilistic]] topics. While a great deal of absurdist fiction may be humorous or irrational in nature, the hallmark of the genre is neither [[comedy]] nor [[literary nonsense|nonsense]], but rather, the study of human behavior under circumstances (whether realistic or fantastical) that appear to be purposeless and [[absurdism|philosophically absurd]]. Absurdist fiction posits little judgment about characters or their actions; that task is left to the reader. Also, the "moral" of the story is generally not explicit, and the themes or characters' realizations—if any —are often ambiguous in nature. Additionally, unlike many other forms of fiction, absurdist works will not necessarily have a traditional [[dramatic structure|plot structure]] (i.e., rising action, climax, falling action, etc.). The absurdist genre grew out of the [[modernist literature]] of the late 19th and early 20th century in direct opposition to the [[Victorian literature]] which was prominent just prior to this period. It was largely influenced by the [[existentialist]] and nihilist movements in [[philosophy]] and the [[Dada]] and [[surrealist]] movements in art. ==Examples== {{Unreferenced section|date=November 2010}} *[[Franz Kafka]] - ''[[The Metamorphosis]]'' (1915), ''[[The Trial]]'' (1925) *[[Luigi Pirandello]] - ''[[Six Characters in Search of an Author]]'' (1921) *[[Svetoslav Minkov]] - ''[[The Lady With the X-Ray Eyes]]'' (1934) *[[Albert Camus]] - ''[[The Stranger (novel)|The Stranger]]'' (1942), ''[[The Plague]]'' (1947), ''[[The Fall (Albert Camus novel)|The Fall]]'' (1956) *[[Eugène Ionesco]] - ''[[The Bald Soprano]]'' (1950), ''[[Rhinoceros (play)|Rhinoceros]]'' (1959) *[[Samuel Beckett]] - ''[[Waiting for Godot]]'' (1952) *[[Harold Pinter]] - ''[[The Birthday Party (play)|The Birthday Party]]'' (1958) *[[Edward Albee]] - ''[[The American Dream (play)|The American Dream]]'' (1961) *[[Joseph Heller]] - ''[[Catch-22]]'' (1961) *[[Kurt Vonnegut]] - ''[[Cat's Cradle]]'' (1963) *[[Tom Stoppard]] - ''[[Rosencrantz & Guildenstern Are Dead]]'' (1966) *[[Luke Rhinehart]] - ''[[The Dice Man]]'' (1971) *[[Tom Robbins]] - ''[[Still Life with Woodpecker]]'' (1980) *[[Patrick Süskind]] - ''[[Perfume (novel)|Perfume]]'' (1985) *[[Paul Auster]] - ''[[The New York Trilogy]]'' (1989) *[[Lemony Snicket]] - ''[[A Series of Unfortunate Events]]'' (1999 - 2006) *[[Ray Fracalossy]] - ''[[Tales From the Vinegar Wasteland]]'' (2006) *[[Gregory Burke]] - ''[[Gagarin Way]]'' (2001) *[[M.
